description: Alterations to existing outbuilding including partial demolition and conversion to storage use (part retrospective)
decision_conditions: The outbuilding by reason of its scale, footprint and proximity to the rear of the main building results in loss of outlook, a detrimental sense of enclosure, and inadequate garden space provision for the ground floor rear flat at no. 30A Randolph Road, Southall to the detriment of the amenity/living conditions of the existing and future residents of that flat contrary to policies 4.1, 5.5 and 5.9 of the Unitary Development Plan 'Plan for the Environment (2004); Supplementary Planning Guidance 13; policies 7A, 7.4 and 7B of the draft Development Management Development Plan Document; policies 7.4, 7.5, and 7.6 of the London Plan (2011); and National Planning Policy Framework (2012). | The outbuilding by reason of its scale and footprint is considered to be excessive in the context of the size of the site, and would be out of scale with the plot of the main building, therefore it is considered to be harmful and unsympathetic to the character and appearance of the area, contrary to policies 4.1, 5.5 and 5.9 of the Unitary Development Plan 'Plan for the Environment (2004); Supplementary Planning Document 4; policies 7A, 7.4 and 7B of the draft Development Management Development Plan Document; policies 7.4, 7.5, and 7.6 of the London Plan (2011); and National Planning Policy Framework (2012). | It is considered that the outbuilding by reason of its scale, footprint, excessive provision of storage beyond that reasonably considered to be required, would fail to be adequately ancillary and subordinate to the existing ground floor flat at no. 30A Randolph Road, Southall contrary to policies 4.1, 5.5 and 5.9 of the Unitary Development Plan 'Plan for the Environment (2004); Supplementary Planning Document  4; policies 7A, 7.4 and 7B of the draft Development Management Development Plan Document; policies 3.5 and 7.6 of the London Plan (2011); and National Planning Policy Framework (2012).
